Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates in Mathematics at Missouri State University
Award.AbstractNarration:
The REU program at the Department of Mathematics, Missouri State University will consist of three eight week long research training projects in the summers of 2016, 2017, and 2018. Each year, it will provide research opportunities in mathematics for twelve undergraduate students from across the nation, especially targeting students from Missouri and neighboring states. Missouri State University believes a rich diversity of people and points of view enhances the quality of learning; as in our previous REUs, special consideration will be given to students coming from traditionally underrepresented groups. The target population consists of talented students from institutions where opportunities for undergraduate research in mathematics are limited. The main goals of this program are to help the students develop their full potential to do research in mathematics, to expose them to the intellectual excitement involved in research, to enable them to be creative and to think independently, and to encourage them to pursue graduate studies.

The research topics will include higher codimension bifurcations in models of neuronal systems, dynamics of networked connectivity models of waterborne disease epidemics, properties of graphs associated to groups, finite point configurations, additive combinatorics, convergence of polygons and polyhedrons, and image processing on hexagonal and triangular domains. Students will work in small groups, and will meet daily with their mentor. Regular progress reports and a final presentation will be given to the entire body of participants. Support will be provided for students to present their results at regional and national conferences. It is expected that some of the research will result in publications in peer-reviewed journals. Students will leave the program with a deeper understanding of mathematics and mathematical research, improved oral and written skills, and a new network of friends and colleagues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This program was aimed at involving undergraduate students in active research, helping them attain a higher level of independence in mathematical reasoning, and encouraging them to pursue graduate studies. During the summers of 2016-2018, the mentors (Reid, Rebaza, Senger, Sun) each guided three undergraduate students in mathematical research projects. The students developed their ability to assimilate the latest research from reading and discussion with their mentors and with other members of the program, and worked on effectively communicating their results by writing and presenting them at seminars at the host institutions and regional and national conferences. Some students published their results in refereed journals. The vast majority of participants went on to graduate school.

Areas of research included:

1. Properties of graphs associated to finite groups. We studied the non-commutative, non-cyclic, and non-nilpotent graphs of groups. We investigated the genus, the eulerian and hamiltonian properties, the chromatic number, and other graph theoretical properties of these graphs.

2. Global stability in models of disease epidemics. We established results on global stability of endemic equilibria in models of Zika and Ebola virus as well as waterborne diseases. Matrix and graph-theoretical methods were applied to construct Lyapunov functions which combined with LaSalle invariance principle provided rigorous proofs of stability. Higher codimension bifurcations were also studied. 

3. Combinatorial properties of finite geometries. We studied point configurations in geometric and arithmetic settings. In particular, we gave bounds for how often k-tuples of points could satisfy some number of distance relations in various settings, from  to vector spaces over finite fields or modules over finite rings (with suitably defined analogies of “distance”). We also studied rainbow or anti-Ramsey type problems in these settings.

4. The geometry of polygonal iteration schemes. We studied the following stochastic version of iteration of polygons. Given a planar polygon, we randomly and independently select a point from the interior of each edge as a vertex to form a new polygon. Repeat the process (resorting to mathematical induction) to generate a stochastic polygon sequence. We showed that such a stochastic polygon sequence converges almost surely to a random point in the convex hull of the vertices of the original polygon.  Furthermore, we established a Gaussian tail bound for the convergence in probability.
